title: Heart-breaking photo shows sullen Staffie-cross stray who boarded bus alone with nowhere to go
text:
Do YOU recognise this dog? If so, email: raven.saunt@mailonline.co.uk

A dog which boarded a bus without an owner has been put into kennels after no one came forward to claim her.

The Staffie-cross stray boarded a First Bus in Bierley that was heading toward Bradford, West Yorkshire, on Wednesday.

The dog was photographed by fellow passenger Gemma Burton as it climbed up on to a seat and sat by itself dejectedly for the rest of the journey.

The Staffie-cross stray boarded a First Bus that was heading toward Bradford, West Yorkshire, on Wednesday and a fellow passenger shared a picture of the pooch online trying to find its owner

Do YOU recognise this dog? If so, email: raven.saunt@mailonline.co.uk

'She did try and get off the bus at one point but it was on the busy main road, so we got her to stay on and someone stayed with her on the bus before she was taken off at Bradford Interchange,' Gemma said speaking to the Yorkshire Evening Post.

Staff were forced to remove the dog 20 minutes later when they reached the final stop in Bradford city centre.

The lonely pooch, which appeared to be wearing a red body harness with gold detail, was then taken into nearby kennels of the rescue charity Yorkshire Rose Dog.

It will stay there for seven days to allow its owner time to come forward.

Staff were forced to remove the dog 20 minutes later when they reached the final stop in Bradford city centre (stock image)

The photograph has since been shared widely online but still no one has come forward 48 hours later.

Social media users were quick to comment on the situation.

One user, Chrissy Wood Johnson, wrote: 'Heartbreaking... I hope this fur baby is claimed or a fabulous forever family adopts.'

Another, Emma Tudorworrall, said: 'If you are unable to find the owner I will happily adopt her.'
description: The dog boarded a First Bus in Bierley that was heading toward Bradford, West Yorkshire, on Wednesday but staff were forced to remove it 20 minutes later when they reached the final stop.
